The London Stock Exchange Group has appointed David Schwimmer, an investment banker with a 20-year career at Goldman Sachs, as its new chief executive to succeed Xavier Rolet.

Mr Schwimmer, a 49-year-old American, was previously global head of market structure and head of metals and mining at the US investment bank. He will begin on August 1.

BE11:17am

[O]rganic revenue growth stood at c. 6.3% for 1H (vs. MSe at 7.3%), suggesting no improvement over what was a disappointing 1Q update earlier in the year. In particular, recurring revenue growth remained weak at c. 6.4%, and Sage called out contract slippage in the enterprise segment. As a result, FY18 guidance has been revised down from c. 8% organic revenue growth to c. 7%; organic operating margin guidance for the FY at c. 27.5% has been maintained. We had commented after 1Q that the weak performance had opened up execution risk, and despite this guidance revision, Sage still needs to accelerate organic growth towards c. 8% in 2H to meet the new guidance and off slightly tougher comps. Sage maintained its recently announced mid-term guidance (org. growth 10% sustainable, org. operating margins at least 27%). We expect low single digit cuts to street earnings estimates for FY18 today, but expect to see the stock down mid-single digits as investors discount heightened risk through the rest of the year and to mid-term guidance. Sage currently trades at c. 17.5x CY19 on MSe. We maintain our view that driving accelerating organic revenue growth in a software company that had been more focused on its installed base is challenging – especially without seeing margins decline to drive the acceleration. We remain underweight.

The 2018 margin guidance unchanged and the stock having been weak into this, one could argue that this is a minor revision to estimates. However, the debate around Sage shifted to the credibility of its longer-term ambition to improve the underlying growth rate and this now seems to validate that this is unlikely to pan out. This could be a meaningful disappointment for those that kept the faith after the last update.

We see little prospect of others expressing an interest, and this now leaves Hammerson free to pursue its controversial acquisition of Intu Properties. Our concerns on the combination remain, and we would not be surprised if shareholder enthusiasm may also have cooled. The shares will trade back down at a material discount to the 790p NAV reported last week. Hold.

red @TKZi can go with gundlach on stock indicies, im expecting a break higher on s&p triangle today (wrong on close below 200dma c 26 handle) but on bitcoin, nah. wake me up at 1-2k.
BE11:42am

And ....

BE11:43am

Our concerns around the acquisition remain

 The all-share acquisition was struck at an exchange ratio of 0.475 Hammerson shares for each Intu share. In our view, this represents a premium for Intu against the historic trading relationship between the two companies and does not reflect their relative positioning.

 Recall that, for Hammerson shareholders, the proposed combination would increase exposure to UK shopping centres (an arguably challenged and overvalued asset class), while at the same time reducing exposure to premium outlets, Ireland, and France.

 With shareholders having had 635p waved in front of them (50% cash and 50% Klépierre shares), has the appetite for the combination with Intu have cooled? We think so – and anticipate the Hammerson General Meeting being more balanced than the Board recommendation may suggest.

 Despite Intu’s defence document pointing to a value of 625p, 425p represented a high water mark and over the subsequent seven years have broadly halved versus the indicative offer.

The EGM, at which Hammerson will require 50%
of its shareholders to approve the all-share offer, will be 28 days afterwards. Intu, on a similar timetable, requires 75% of its shareholders to approve the deal. Whilst we expect the Intu shareholder vote to pass comfortably, there may be some disquiet from
Hammerson shareholders, but with significant cross shareholding between the two, we expect Hammerson shareholders to also approve the deal. Of the 25 largest institutional investors in Hammerson, 20 also own stakes in Intu; these shareholders own a combined 63% of Hammerson and 71% of Intu.

BE11:59am

While we slightly surprised by the timing of the stake build and announcement that IAG
might initiate takeover negotiations, we have suggested for some time that this was a
rationale move by the group.
The key positive is clearly the potential to acquire a major distributor on the North Atlantic,
with the likely benefit of more stable pricing in this critical profit generator for the business.
At the same time, the acquisition would allow IAG to substantially grow its footprint in the
emerging low cost-long haul market which management believes is a sustainable high
growth sector following the success they have enjoyed with the launch of its own LEVEL
brand. Additionally, NAS's dual order book can be better utilised across the broader group,
while offer the enlarged scale to deliver better leasing and aircraft purchase terms.
In terms of the possible cost, we see a total EV (including capitalized leases) of circa €7bn,
more than doubling IAG's forecast position at the end of this year. While a significant step,
this would leave the combined ratio at 2x EBITDAR, a level that management would be
comfortable with, especially given circa €1bn post dividend free cash flow forecast for both
FY19 and FY20.

Miss Piggy @TKZ: it means that will no longer trend downwards.
BE11:59am

More challenging is the impact on the group's P&L given NAS's marginal profitability. As
such, restructuring of the business, renegotiation on lease terms, integrating base operations
(especially at Gatwick, Madrid and Barcelona) would be critical. Further, there is also an
argument that some of the intra-EU routes would better fit with another airline (Ryanair step
forward?), with only 13.3% of NAS’s and 6.4% of IAG’s network directly competing.
Overall, we think that this could prove to be a highly attractive deal for IAG over
the medium term. What we don't believe, though, is that IAG is going to pay a
significant premium for the equity component (just because it represents less than
20% of the overall cost). In fact, with the deal really in the hands of the lessors
and bankers, NAS equity holders may be disappointed by the share price
performance given that its operations remain under pressure from rising oil prices
and the cost of such rapid growth.

Maverick Cheers Bryce
Miss Piggy US earnings, midday
